data.title: Weapon / Armament Burst limitations
data.body:
Our current hardcoded behaviour of weapons with more than 1 Burst has two caveats that might be fine for our shipping mods (for the most part), but can get annoying for 3rd-party mods and prevent some balance-sensitive fixes to some weapons in our shipping mods, too (we could get rid of all these delayed warheads on the RA vulcan if these limitations were adressed).

Those caveats are:
- [ ] as soon as the original target is killed, the attacking actor either immediately fires any remaining bursts at the next available target(s), or immediately stops shooting (if no other target is present).
- [ ] depleted bursts are not replenished until all remaining bursts have been fired.

Ideally, it should be optionally possible to make weapons
- fire any remaining bursts at the last position of the killed target and only switch to next target after that (would allow using `Burst: 5` instead of delayed warheads on RA vulcan, and "feel more right" for RA cruisers and TS Juggernauts, too)
- make all depleted bursts replenish after a cooldown (Weapon.ReloadDelay after last burst was fired, normally) even if there were bursts remaining

Alternatives:
- somewhat hacky, but easy: if target was destroyed, set remaining bursts to zero and trigger reloading
- Propose the use of `AmmoPool` to fix the 2nd caveat (although that still wouldn't adress the 1st).

data.title: Fix RangeMultiplier regression.
data.body: The Default suffix was incosistent with the others and wasn't applied everywhere - case in point https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/bleed/OpenRA.Mods.Common/Traits/Armament.cs#L149 - which made it broken.

data.title: Fix jumpjet flying death animations
data.body: This fixes a regression from #12999 (Jumpjet husks didn't have the `Health` trait, so it span forever) and hooks up the splat/spash animations when it hits the ground.

data.title: Fullscreen (Legacy) is broken on HiDPI systems
data.body: Only the top-left quarter of the screen is shown.

data.title: Overhaul packaging scripts
data.body:
This reworks our packaging scripts to remove ancient cruft and provide a clean and more robust base for the mod template's packaging scripts.

The only expected user-visible change is that we no longer ship the trait and lua html files.  These monolithic files need to be broken up into proper multi-page websites, and shipping them with the installers just complicates that.

I have already tested all the packages on all the OSes, but if anybody wants to confirm then [see here](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/xtz3f1ofszstidc/AACiyZws2BaO48pMG0zwtrwca?dl=0).  The `test` versions are built on macOS, and the `linuxtest` versions are built on Ubuntu 16.04.

data.title: Expose the drop-disguise-when-attacking aspect to yaml.
data.body: Also adds Damaged for more usecases.

data.title: Fix Player Earnings - building cancellation/selling
data.body:
Fixes #13212.
Building cancellation/selling doesn't increase player earnings.

data.title: Earnings per min calculation : building cancellation
data.body:
It seems to me that building cancellation is a source of income in the earnings graph.

You can see here a game against an AI, that I intentionnally blocked in debug (with wire fences). Thus the AI was trying to build, then cancelling every time. The AI has a steady "income" of 2500/min, although having no source of income.

![openra-2017-04-29t182145220z](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8159198/25557833/40616154-2d1a-11e7-93ea-953cbf55222c.png)

data.title: Add new d2k mod logo
data.body:
This adds Warman's new logo to the d2k loadscreen and packaging.  Closes #13121.

https://github.com/OpenRA/ArtSrc/tree/d2k-logo is ready to merge onto the artsrc master once this is done.

I have tested that this works correctly on all platforms, but if you want to try for yourself there are packages for [windows](https://www.dropbox.com/s/o4s0ueuq6c0juhy/OpenRA-logotest-201704229.exe?dl=1), [macOS](https://www.dropbox.com/s/qtnytok77iw00qt/OpenRA-logotest-201704229.dmg?dl=1), and [Debian/Ubuntu](https://www.dropbox.com/s/dhnixjc1so8e8yy/openra_logotest.201704229_all.deb?dl=1).

data.title: Production-Exit types w/ Spawning LST outside of SPEN

milestone.title: Future
milestone.description: This milestone is meant for stuff we want fixed, but don't have a timeline for yet. Also a collection of pull requests left undone.

data.body: Transport (and boats with the cheat) spawn outside of the submarine pen. I plan on using `ExitInfo.Type` in `Targetable` as a source of targetable positions for matching targeting type(s) for enter activities while other traits such as possibly `Building`, possibly `TargetablePositions`, and/or possibly `Health` provide targetable positions for attack activities, etc.

data.title: Make Airstrikes a "toggle-able" Option
data.body:
In OpenCNC, there's four tech levels:
- Low : Everything except stuff unlocked by having a Comm.Center
- Medium : Everything except the top tier buildings (Adv.Comm.Center/Temple)
- No Powers : Everything except airstrikes and nukes
- Unrestricted : Everything

I feel like the airstrikes should be something that could be turned on/off in the menu before starting a match instead of something exclusive to Unrestricted. Most of the game, you get access to Airstrikes before you even learn about superweapons. Airstrikes shouldn't be pooled together with the "end game" weapons since they're not even classified as "super". You get access to airstrikes in the third mission of the GDI campaign which is pretty much a tutorial mission since you're still learning how everything works.

I know in cnc.net they had an option to turn on/off airstrikes from the menu before matches in case players wanted to have matches with them but, without superweapons.
Players should be able to utilize them at any tech level that grants access to the Comm. Center rather than being limited to a "nothing or everything" based tech system.

Seeing as the RA side has "No Superweapons" as a tech level but allows bombing runs, making airstrikes toggle-able in CNC wouldn't hurt.

data.title: Be able to set NoKey('unknown') to a hotkey.
data.body:
First off i noticed that when i remove all hotkeys in settings.yaml it gets rewritten with default values that doesnt even get written out in the file (if you change a hotkey in the game it gets added into settings.yaml)

Its a small concern but my biggest one is not being able to 'delete' a key ingame so its value becomes 'unknown' that some hotkeys have by default. Instead i have to move keys i dont use to a corner of my keyboard to isolate em out of my game. This might sound silly but i do not like hotkeys hotkeyed if i dont use em.

The 'unknown' value maybe can be set but if so i dont know how to. 

Also i dont think its reasonable you can have multiple things hotkeyed to same key. It should be overwritten and become 'unknown'.

data.title: Using SHIFT+key to build units stopped working.
data.body: Had my hotkeys set in a grid like 1 2 3 q w e etc with SHIFT to build units that worked in some previous version. Stopped working now. CTRL+key to build units do work though.

data.title: AI Defense Building and Power Distribution
data.body:
So far, the new updates been working pretty well but, the AI's base building skills still needs some work.
The AI always builds Maginot Lines. 
In layman's terms, it always builds defenses in a straight line along one side of the base's farthest boundaries and disregards building them inside their base or any other side of their base if the opponents set starting point isn't nearby that side of the base; along forces to easily flank them (given the terrain allows them to).
Additionally, the AI always packs its defenses next to each other in an almost modular layout with little to no space between them.
 
While I'm not sure how programming AI works, I just thought I'd bring it to attention for the sake of players that play more offline than online. 

Here's some examples from Tiberian Dawn:
![line defense](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25445701/0a710206-2a7d-11e7-81aa-0aeaefec3b67.png)

The GDI base in this image is directly south of the NOD base in the first image.
![maginot gdi](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25446142/9642fec8-2a7e-11e7-827f-d5d647bfa483.png)

Here's an example in RA on Path Beyond.
![ra maginot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25446774/a4322de0-2a80-11e7-8a1b-7afdfad43526.png)
To clarify that neither of the bases are mine, I don't have a War Factory built yet so I don't have access to Tesla Coils yet. 

I'm not entirely sure if it's scripted for the AI to instinctively build it's defenses in a straight line based on which direction it is in relation to enemy's starting point but, the method seems a bit too consistent. 

Seeing as neither OpenRA or OpenCNC use the original building system (build out as far as the terrain allows until it looks like you spilled paint on a map), I could recommend one possible way of fixing this for both the AI and base-centric players (like myself). Heck, if every player wasn't so set in Rush tactics, I'd build a base as elaborate as the one in the RA shellmap if I was given enough time to.
(random note: I actually made a sandbox map just to showcase the examples below)

![example 1 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25447827/976461b0-2a84-11e7-85f3-6225edd1aff2.png)

To prevent AI and players from building their bases so far apart that they can't place defenses near base structures, give regular building their own "build circle" in which defense structures can be placed even if the circle reaches outside of the base's "build circle". That way the defenses aren't always outlining the base limits with vital structures being left uncomfortably close to No Man's Land (essentially everything outside of the build circle). 
I noticed this method sort of applies with walls but, maybe base defenses could use a similar mechanic since most of the time you'll end up with a maze of sandbags just outside of where all your base defenses are.

By implementing this, the could be less defense edging and instead, more diverse layouts.
![example 1 3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25448339/197296e4-2a86-11e7-9cad-4b0d3b8df0c5.png)

Going back to how the old build system isn't present, since there's no way to build near captured buildings like in Red Alert 2, defense circles could be used for captureable structures as well. 
That way, there isn't too much micromanagement with reinforcing defenseless buildings with infantry and tanks.

Before
![field barn](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25451615/c424a6f4-2a90-11e7-9bfc-bc7fa02027d9.png)
After
![tech defense](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25448902/1066d6d0-2a88-11e7-8741-71573bea51ba.png)

In terms of actual habits that could be implemented for the AI, here's some ways to improve on it.
I know the "Turtle" AI just spams defenses more that anything else but, maybe it could be given some techniques borrowed from Red Alert 2 like building fortified perimeters around vital structures and superweapons. 

![fortified buildings](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/25542788/25449816/001f0c4a-2a8b-11e7-9733-d983bfdf4d7b.png)

Back in Red Alert 2, the AI had a tendency to box-in their superweapons so they couldn't be sabotaged or immediately hit by tank rounds. In OpenRA it could be taken a step further by programming the AI to build a perimeter and even a small pocket of defenses around the superweapon to make Orca and Apache raids less cheap when playing offline.

-----
One other thing I noticed is that the AI only builds enough power plants to support almost exactly the amount it needs and never any emergency backup power. I could be mistaken with this observation though because I tend to lose track of how many power plants I destroy. Just thought I'd mention this since it sort of affects the defenses.

-----

Again, I know nothing about programming outside of the bare minimum but, I just thought I'd share my idea to help the game grow even further. I'm still experimenting with the game's AI to see how much it's changed since the previous version and I can say the pathfinding has definitely improved because it doesn't get stuck at long cliff lines as often as it used to and the "fast vehicle behind slow vehicle humping" seems to have died down a bit (not sure if it was actually fixed but, it seems like something changed). What I'm trying to say is "nice work on the update". 

Do whatever you wish with my feedback. It's your game :)

data.title: Fix TargetPosition targeting and give D2k buildings better hit-shapes
data.body:
The discussion in #13165 leans towards footprint-based hit-shapes, so I've built on that plus the initial review feedback.
Rather than updating the old PR, I've decided to file this separately (mostly due to the branch name, but also to keep the discussion and actual reviewing a bit separate).

This is basically the spiritual successor to #10383 and actually scavenged some code from there.

The commit count makes this look more intimidating than it really is, only the first 3 commits contain code and the individual yaml commits are small.

data.title: ActorExts.AppearsFriendlyTo Simplification
data.body: If `stance == Stance.Ally` is true, then `ActorExts.AppearsFriendlyTo` returns `true` on line 45; therefore, `stance == Stance.Ally` on line 50 is always `false`. This just simplifies it. (I know that the compiler *might* do that already.)

data.title: Fix Spectator can cause lag by holding hotkey
data.body: Fixes #13189.

data.title: Remove ChatSettings.NickName, use PlayerName always as default
data.body: Closes  #9728.

data.title: Out of Date Documentation - make install-all
data.body:
The documentation (https://github.com/OpenRA/OpenRA/blob/bleed/INSTALL.md#linux) states to run make install-all to install, but that doesn't appear to be correct any more as it results in "make: *** No rule to make target 'install-all'.  Stop.".

The Makefile itself seems to imply the correct form is now just "make install" so it's a simple fix.

data.title: Correct make install command for Linux
data.body: No-longer "install-all".
